discharge_summary: 1 severe acute respiratory syndrome, due to coronavirus. 2 new septic shock 01/14, fever hypotension, 3 acneiform eruption secondary to corticosteroid therapy, 4 pneumomediastinum airway injury? subcutaneous emphysema after depronation worsening ventilatory status, 5 new septic shock on 01/24 start of vasoactive drug, leukocytosis, 6 reactive adrenal insufficiency? hyperkalemia hyponatremia shock. admission: 01/06/2020, discharge: 03/03/2020, stay: 01 m 24 d 18 h, location: ward, payer: sus. clinical history [person] reports that he started with headache, myalgia and dry cough on 12/28, persisting with the same until 12/31, when he sought care and was prescribed prednisone, azithromycin, zinc and symptomatics. [person] started taking prescribed medications and on 02/01 he started with a fever, having performed a PCR for coronavirus with no result yet. On 03/01 he presented respiratory discomfort, having sought care on 04/01, when antibiotic therapy was changed to intravenous; the family member does not know which medication, however, there was no indication for hospital admission. [person] persisted with respiratory discomfort, having been hospitalized in the early hours of the same day. Emergency care unit report of oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, progressively worsening. He was admitted to the emergency unit on 06/01 with severe pulmonary involvement on chest x-ray, and was continued on antibiotic therapy initiated in the emergency care unit, ceftriaxone daily on 05/01 and prophylactic dexamethasone and enoxaparin initiated. He was admitted to [organization] on 07/01, requiring orotracheal intubation and central venous catheterization. He presented septic shock on 14/01, and his antibiotic regimen was changed. He remained in bed at [organization]. He developed new septic shock on 24/01, and began using fluconazole for fungal coverage. He developed pneumomediastinum on 26/01 due to airway injury, and underwent conservative treatment. He underwent tracheostomy on 29/01. He presented reactive adrenal insufficiency and acneiform rash related to corticosteroid therapy, in addition to diarrhea treated empirically with the hypothesis of pseudomembranous colitis. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. He presented progressive clinical improvement and was transferred to [organization], where he remained stable. He underwent fibroscopy and was evaluated by speech therapy on 02/03, with no residual airway injury identified and a soft diet was released. He was decannulated on 03/03, remaining eupneic and in condition to be discharged. Good general condition, alert, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, Glasgow 15, oxygen saturation 94% in room air with capped tracheostomy, respiratory rate 28 inspirations per minute, muscle strength grade 4 in upper and lower limbs, regular heart rhythm in two beats, normal sound sounds without murmurs. Heart rate 76, vesicular breath sounds present, symmetrical, without adventitious sounds, without use of accessory muscles. Flaccid, flat abdomen, painless to palpation, without masses or visceromegaly. Extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, without edema, absence of swelling of the calves. Presence of pressure ulcer in the left lower limb, without signs of infection. Tracheostomy fibroscopy. I advise [person] on outpatient follow-up visits for: head and neck surgery on 03/15 speech therapy on 03/25 reassessment of diet physiatry to be scheduled I advise [person] on home care for tracheostomy orifice, diet, exercise and care. I prescribe symptomatic medications. Aminc, head and neck surgery, speech therapy, physiatry. Good general condition, slim, conscious and oriented, moving all 4 limbs actively with grade 4 muscle strength, still not able to walk alone. Tracheostomy orifice occluded with dressing and eating a soft diet. No pain complaints.

[person] started taking prescribed medications and on 02/01 he started with a fever, having performed a PCR for coronavirus with no result yet. On 03/01 he presented respiratory discomfort, having sought care on 04/01, when antibiotic therapy was changed to intravenous; the family member does not know which medication, however, there was no indication for hospital admission. [person] persisted with respiratory discomfort, having been hospitalized in the early hours of the same day. Emergency care unit report of oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, progressively worsening. He was admitted to the emergency unit on 06/01 with severe pulmonary involvement on chest x-ray, and was continued on antibiotic therapy initiated in the emergency care unit, ceftriaxone daily on 05/01 and prophylactic dexamethasone and enoxaparin initiated. He was admitted to [organization] on 07/01, requiring orotracheal intubation and central venous catheterization. He presented septic shock on 14/01, and his antibiotic regimen was changed. He remained in bed at [organization]. He developed new septic shock on 24/01, and began using fluconazole for fungal coverage. He developed pneumomediastinum on 26/01 due to airway injury, and underwent conservative treatment. He underwent tracheostomy on 29/01. He presented reactive adrenal insufficiency and acneiform rash related to corticosteroid therapy, in addition to diarrhea treated empirically with the hypothesis of pseudomembranous colitis. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. He presented progressive clinical improvement and was transferred to [organization], where he remained stable. He underwent fibroscopy and was evaluated by speech therapy on 02/03, with no residual airway injury identified and a soft diet was released. He was decannulated on 03/03, remaining eupneic and in condition to be discharged. Good general condition, alert, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, Glasgow 15, oxygen saturation 94% in room air with capped tracheostomy, respiratory rate 28 inspirations per minute, muscle strength grade 4 in upper and lower limbs, regular heart rhythm in two beats, normal sound sounds without murmurs. Heart rate 76, vesicular breath sounds present, symmetrical, without adventitious sounds, without use of accessory muscles. Flaccid, flat abdomen, painless to palpation, without masses or visceromegaly. Extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, without edema, absence of swelling of the calves. Presence of pressure ulcer in the left lower limb, without signs of infection. Tracheostomy fibroscopy. I advise [person] on outpatient follow-up visits for: head and neck surgery on 03/15 speech therapy on 03/25 reassessment of diet physiatry to be scheduled I advise [person] on home care for tracheostomy orifice, diet, exercise and care. I prescribe symptomatic medications. Aminc, head and neck surgery, speech therapy, physiatry. Good general condition, slim, conscious and oriented, moving all 4 limbs actively with grade 4 muscle strength, still not able to walk alone. Tracheostomy orifice occluded with dressing and eating a soft diet. No pain complaints.

He had several episodes of vomiting, which started 5 days ago and improved 2 days ago. His family called [organization] due to his condition. During the evaluation by the transport team, [person] reported an episode of fever (38.3 °C) and dry cough since 06/10. During hospitalization at [organization], he was given antibiotic therapy and referred [person] to our services. His syncope did not recur. He reported diarrhea for 15 days and improvement for 3 days, which is why his chemotherapy cycle was suspended. Upon admission, [person] was hemodynamically stable, breathing with a mask with a reservoir at 10 L/min, without respiratory distress, and denying any complaints at the moment. He is afebrile. Edema of the lower limbs, crackles, and reduced vesicular breath sounds on the left. [person] was pale and emaciated. No relevant results. Pleural fluid puncture and chest drain. Pneumonia, no pending tests. Antibiotic therapy: cefepime and clarithromycin. [person] evolves into death.
